text:
<https://wagerr.com/>
<https://wagerr.com/sportsbook>
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aqfuaM1I3Rs>

I’m not sure how many of you are familiar with blockchain projects. Here’s a blockchain sportsbook with a dedicated token called WGR, it allows you to bet against the blockchain itself rather than a human bookie.

Odds get published by nodes of the network. The blockchain is programmed to accept bets and pay winnings based on these odds. When bets are placed, tokens get burned. When winnings are paid, tokens get minted.  When minting, a small percentage get burned (deflationary mechanism of the token) and another gets put into a bucket to reward people who run nodes of the network.

elements.text:

Odds get published by nodes of the network. The blockchain is programmed to accept bets and pay winnings based on these odds. When bets are placed, tokens get burned. When winnings are paid, tokens get minted.  When minting, a small percentage get burned (deflationary mechanism of the token) and another gets put into a bucket to reward people who run nodes of the network.

text: What do you mean "bet against the blockchain itself" and who sets these odds? I remember looking into this along with other crypto type betting projects FUN BETR and SPADE (lost a fair bit of money buying into the ICOs of the last 2) but none of them seems to have advanced much and the only one I would go near right now is Augur to be honest.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Odds get published by nodes of the network, currently these special “oracle nodes” are run by the developers but in the future anyone will be able to run these, there will be a consensus mechanism for odds publishing. Betting against the blockchain… re-read many times what I wrote three posts up, although it’s an innovative concept that’s not easy to understand, I get it.

text: Sorry <@USWDY5P7G> but I would not touch a platform like that unless it was paying out in stable coins. WGR is currently ranked 688 and has dropped 11% in last 24 hours. Thats not for me I am afraid.

elements.text: Sorry
but I would not touch a platform like that unless it was paying out in stable coins. WGR is currently ranked 688 and has dropped 11% in last 24 hours. Thats not for me I am afraid.

text: No probs. Using stablecoins would require another human on the other side that takes your bets and underwrites the risk. Having a dedicated token allows the blockchain to “be the bookie” and burn/mint tokens. As for the WGR price, I can only say that DOGE has zero utility and a market cap of $9b, while WGR has a use case but it hasn’t been marketed at all, hence the low token valuation.

elements.text: No probs. Using stablecoins would require another human on the other side that takes your bets and underwrites the risk. Having a dedicated token allows the blockchain to “be the bookie” and burn/mint tokens. As for the WGR price, I can only say that DOGE has zero utility and a market cap of $9b, while WGR has a use case but it hasn’t been marketed at all, hence the low token valuation.

text: Plus the taxman will want his cut as crypto profits (which I am sure this would be seen as) would need you to declare to the taxman for CG tax. Not sure UK crypto tax regulations are sufficiently advanced enough yet to waive tax due because the funds were achieved by gambling.

elements.text: Plus the taxman will want his cut as crypto profits (which I am sure this would be seen as) would need you to declare to the taxman for CG tax. Not sure UK crypto tax regulations are sufficiently advanced enough yet to waive tax due because the funds were achieved by gambling.

text: DOGE is shit everyone knows that. But this is part of the problem - you place a bet and your winnings could be eroded or augmented based on market sentiment.

elements.text: DOGE is shit everyone knows that. But this is part of the problem - you place a bet and your winnings could be eroded or augmented based on market sentiment.

text: Oracles publish odds. People bet against the blockchain using apps or the web sportsbook. When event ends, oracles tell the blockchain about the score. The blockchain mints new tokens and sends them to the gambler’s address.

elements.text: Oracles publish odds. People bet against the blockchain using apps or the web sportsbook. When event ends, oracles tell the blockchain about the score. The blockchain mints new tokens and sends them to the gambler’s address.

text: And who owns the oracles? Doesn't sound like a very decentralised approach to market resolution.

elements.text: And who owns the oracles? Doesn't sound like a very decentralised approach to market resolution.

text: The only non-decentralised thing at the moment is odds publishing, which is done by oracles owned by the developer team. As I said, in the future there will be 2,000 oracles up for grabs that anyone with a big enough WGR stake will be able to run to publish odds. Building a solid odds publishing consensus tech requires time, as you can imagine.

elements.text: The only non-decentralised thing at the moment is odds publishing, which is done by oracles owned by the developer team. As I said, in the future there will be 2,000 oracles up for grabs that anyone with a big enough WGR stake will be able to run to publish odds. Building a solid odds publishing consensus tech requires time, as you can imagine.
